Research Paper F127 assisted synthesis of Bi promoted Co3O4 catalyst for catalyzing N2O decomposition in presence of impurity gases Keyi Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Project administration Investigation Formal analysis Yuanting Du Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Yang Li Software Funding acquisition Xingkun Qi Validation Investigation Weijun Shan Methodology Data curation Haibiao Yu Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Ying Xiong Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis ⁎ College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China College of Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 PR China College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this paper, Bi promoted Co3O4 catalysts used for catalyzing N2O decomposition were successfully prepared by improved sol-gel method with the assistance of F127. It was found that the doping of additive Bi not only did not change the unique “Yardang Landform” microstructure of the 3.0F-Co3O4, but also prompted Co3O4 to expose more active crystal planes, such as (422), (533) and (620). Moreover, the doping of the additive Bi also enhanced the catalyst's specific surface area, and further weakened the surface Co-O bond. The optimum 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst achieved >88 % N2O conversion (2000 ppmv N2O/Ar, GHSV=20,000 h −1) at 300 °C, and its corresponding TOF value increased from 1.50 × 10−3 s −1 for 3.0F-Co3O4 to 3.63 × 10−3 s −1. Meanwhile, the Ea of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was as low as 47.0 kJ mol−1. Most importantly, the catalyst has good resistance to O2 and H2O. Under the harsh condition (both 5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol.% H2O were coexisted in the reaction system), the N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst can be stable above 90 % at 400 °C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N2O decomposition Bi CO3O4 F127 Impurity gases Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide (N2O) is regarded as the third largest greenhouse gas after CO2 and CH4 [1]. Moreover, it contributes to the destruction of the stratospheric ozone layer significantly due to its long lifetime in the atmosphere [2]. Chemical manufacturing plants emit large amounts of N2O, with 70–90 % of industrial emissions coming from adipic acid and nitric acid plants [3,4]. This part of N2O emissions is rising year by year and cause a serious threat to the atmospheric environment and human health [5]. Hence, it is important to efficiently reduce and control the emission of N2O polluting gases. There are common methods which have been developed to reduce N2O emission, including high temperature thermal decomposition [6,7], selective catalytic reduction [8,9] and direct catalytic decomposition [10,11]. So far, direct catalytic decomposition has been recognized as the most promising method for eliminating N2O due to its high efficiency and no secondary pollution. Among many kinds of reported N2O decomposition catalysts, the cobalt-based catalysts are universally acknowledged as the most remarkable catalysts revealing excellent N2O decomposition performance at mild temperature [10-13]. However, they generally face the problem that it is difficult to maintain high N2O conversion under the interference of impurity gases, such as O2, NO x and H2O. Hence, the further development of cobalt-based catalysts for solving the N2O pollution emitted by actual chemical production to meet the market level has become a problem many scholars are committed to solve. Recently, in the process of catalyst development, the structural and morphological changes derived from the differences in preparation method or the additions of additives ultimately affect the catalytic N2O decomposition performance for cobalt-based catalysts. In many reports of cobalt-based metal oxide catalysts, researchers have mostly introduced additives in the synthesis of Co3O4 catalysts to improve their catalytic performance for N2O decomposition, such as Mn [14], Ce [15], Pb [16], large radius Bi [17,18] and rare [19] and noble metal [20]. In particular, the additive Bi has excellent performance in improving catalyst activity and impurity gases resistance. Tursun et al. [18] found that the addition of Bi to Co3O4 catalysts by co-precipitation method could decrease the average crystallite size of Co3O4, thus greatly enlarge its specific surface area, and increase the number of active sites, which enabled the catalysts to realize 100 % N2O conversion at 400 °C. In addition, it was found that the Bi promoted Co3O4 catalyst exhibited excellent CO2 resistance properties. Apart from catalytic N2O decomposition, Li et al. [21] also prepared Co3O4 nanoparticles/Bi2O3 nanosheets catalyst with special morphology by sol-gel method to improve its catalytic isopropyl alcohol (IPA) decomposition performance. Their results demonstrated that the synergistic effect between Bi2O3 and Co3O4 contributed to the generation of oxygen vacancies, which further enhanced the catalytic activity of the prepared sample. The increase in number of oxygen vacancies is also beneficial for catalyzing N2O decomposition. In addition to additives modification, different synthesis conditions can also greatly influence the catalytic activity of cobalt-based catalysts for N2O decomposition. Li et al. [22] prepared a series of various morphologies Co3O4 spinel for N2O decomposition by hydrothermal method, such as nanocube (NCCo3O4), nanosheet (NS-Co3O4), nanorod (NR-Co3O4), and nanopolyhedra (NPL-Co3O4). They pointed out that oxygen vacancies are more prone to occur on the (001) crystal plane compared to the (110) crystal plane, which requires lower activation energy (30 kJ.mol−1). In our recent study [23], it was found that the introduction of F127 (PEO106PPO70PEO106, Mav=12,600) during Co3O4 catalyst preparation by sol-gel method can create rich number of “edges and corners” with unique “Yardang Landform” microstructure for Co3O4 crystallite. Meanwhile, the prepared 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst mainly expose (400) and (511) crystal planes, which possess high catalytic activity for N2O decomposition. Based on this distinctive microstructure, the optimal 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited 60 % N2O conversion for long time under the simulated exhaust atmosphere of nitric acid plant. The reason for this was that P123 as an amphiphilic triblock copolymer will combine with each other to form micelles when mixed with water at low concentrations [24], and affects the microscopic morphology of the prepared catalyst. Samsudin et al. have added F127 as a surfactant in the synthesis of TiO2, which increased the specific surface area of the metal oxide TiO2 and exposed more crystal planes [25]. Herein, based on the above published studies, the large radius metal element Bi promoted Co3O4 catalyst was prepared by improved sol-gel method with the assistance of F127, and used for eliminating N2O pollution under the simulated the exhaust atmosphere of nitric acid plant. The effects of additive Bi and the introduction of F127 in the catalyst's preparing process on the microstructure, surface chemical properties and catalytic performance were studied by various characterization methods. At the same time, the catalytic activity and stability of the prepared catalyst for decomposing N2O under the influence of impurity gases, such as O2, NO x , and H2O, were also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Co(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Company. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, concentrated HNO3 and Na2CO3 were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company. Pluronic F127 (PEO106PPO70PEO106, Mav=12,600) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All the reagents were analytically pure. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The Bi promoted Co3O4 catalysts were prepared via improved sol-gel method with the assistance of F127, and the preparation process was similar to that reported in our previous study [23]. Firstly, 5.0 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O and a certain amount of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O as precursors were added into the mixed solution, which containing 3.0 g F127, 2.4 g concentrated HNO3 and 17 g distilled water. Subsequently, the obtained solution was continuously stirred at 90 °C to obtain a transparent gel. Then, it was dried at 120 °C overnight. Finally, the obtained sample was calcined in a shaft crucible furnace in air with a stepwise temperature increase of 150 °C for 1 h, 250 °C for 0.5 h, and 400 °C for 2 h. The prepared catalysts were named as 3.0F-Bi x Co (x = 0–0.04, 0.2), where 3.0F represents the 3.0 g of F127, and x represents the mole ratio of Bi3+/Co2+. For comparation, when x = 0, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was prepared, when F127 was absence, the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst was prepared. Both 3.0F-Co3O4 and 0F-Co3O4 have already been reported in our previous study [23]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The details of Powdered X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Nitrogen adsorption isotherms, X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) characterizations for prepared 3.0F-Bi x Co catalysts were in accordance with those described in our previous study [23]. 2.4 Activity test and kinetics study The activity test of catalysts for N2O decomposition was performed in the tubular quartz reactor (height = 32 cm and inner diameter = 4 mm), which loaded 0.200 g of 40–60 mesh catalyst. The reaction gas mixture consisted of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar with or without some of impurity gases (5 vol% O2, 2 vol% H2O or 100 ppmv NO) with a total flow rate of 50 mL/min. Firstly, the tested catalyst was pretreated by the pure Ar at 400 °C, 50 mL/min for 30 min to remove impurities adsorbed on the catalyst surface before conducting the activity test. Then, the steady-state catalytic activity was analyzed at temperatures from 250 to 400 °C, in step of 50 °C. The signal intensity of N2O in the flue gas was monitored by Varian GC3800 gas chromatograph (porapak Q column, 3 m) equipped with TCD detector. The efficiency of N2O conversion was measured at each temperature as follows: (1) N 2 O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ N 2 O ] i n − [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N 2 O ] i n × 100 ( % ) Where [N2O]in and [N2O]out represent the total N2O concentration at the inlet and outlet of the tubular quartz reactor. Furthermore, due to the fact that the direct catalytic N2O decomposition over cobalt-based catalysts belongs to the first order kinetics reaction [26-28], some kinetic parameters, including specific reaction rate, rate constant, activation energy and turn over frequency, were measured and calculated according to the method reported in our previous studies [29,30]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural structure characterization of the catalysts In order to investigate the effect of the addition of Bi on the crystalline phase and grain size of Co3O4 in the catalysts, the 3.0F-Bi x Co (x = 0 - 0.04, 0.2) catalysts were characterized by XRD. As shown in the Fig. 1 , when Bi/Co ratio was between 0 - 0.04, the Bi-doped catalysts all exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks of spinel Co3O4 structure (JCPDS 43–1003), and no other crystal phases can be observed. In addition, the XRD diffraction peak at 2θ = 36–38° were magnified, as shown in the right panel of the Fig. 1. It can be found that no obvious diffraction peak shift appeared for 3.0F-Bi x Co (x = 0–0.04) catalysts after Bi incorporation. The above experimental phenomena are likely to be due to two main reasons: firstly, the ionic radius of Bi3+ (103pm) is greater than that of Co2+ (65pm), so it is difficult for Bi species to enter the Co3O4 lattice to form a solid solution under the given catalyst preparation conditions (improved sol-gel method). Second, the amount of Bi added as the additive in the catalyst is very small, which results in it not being able to form an effective crystalline phase with Co that can be detected by XRD, such as BiCoO3 perovskite phase. To analyze the morphology of Bi in the catalyst, the 3.0F-Bi0.2Co catalyst with Bi content of 33 wt.% was also characterized by XRD, as shown in the Fig. 1. In addition to the characteristic diffraction peaks of Co3O4, the diffraction peaks belonging to Bi2O3 at 2θ = 27.9°, 32.7°, 46.2°, 55.5° and 74.5° (JCPDS 78–1793) were observed for the 3.0F-Bi0.2Co catalyst. The result indicated that the additive Bi was present in the form of Bi2O3 in the 3.0F-Bi0.2Co catalysts. On this basis, there is enough reason to believe that Bi should exist in the same chemical state (Bi2O3) in the prepared 3.0F-Bi x Co catalyst with low Bi content (x = 0 - 0.04) by improved sol-gel method. The similar conclusions have also been obtained for other catalysts reported in our previous studies [18,29,30]. Correspondingly, the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore-size distribution of 3.0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalysts were presented in the Fig. 2 . As shown in the Fig. 2 A, the isotherms of tested two catalysts all exhibited the mixed type pattern with a H3 hysteresis loop. It means the surfactant F127 imparts a complex mesoporous structure to the sample, which is not a perfect fit for standard adsorption isotherm model. The noticeable rise in volume of the adsorbed N2 in the relative pressure range of 0.8 - 1.0 was observed, which indicated the formation of a mesoporous structure is attributed to the accumulation of microcrystalline [31]. In addition, it can be found that the pore size was in the order of 3.0F-Co3O4 (3.4 nm) > 3.0F-Bi0.015Co (2.0 nm), as shown in the Fig. 2 B. It indicated that the presence of Bi was more conducive to the formation of small gaps and defects. The BET specific surface area of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was 38 m2 g −1, which was about 1.9 times to that (20 m2 g −1) of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst. This means that the introduction of Bi can greatly increase the surface area of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst. The SEM photos in Fig. 3 A and B depicted the particle structure of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst at different magnifications, which unveiled its resemblance to the previously synthesized 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst [23]. The doping Bi during synthesis process still resulted in an irregular particle structure. Furthermore, Fig. 3 C-F presented the results of EDX elemental surface scanning on the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst, distinctly demonstrating a uniform distribution of both Co and Bi elements within the catalyst with no presence of other elements except for Bi, Co, and O. The weight% of Bi on the surface of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was 0.32 %. The result also confirmed the high dispersion of Bi2O3 on the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst. In our previous studies, it was proved that the incorporation of F127 induced the appearance of special microstructures and the exposure of high active crystal planes [23]. To explore whether this is also the case for 3.0F-Bi0.015Co, TEM and HRTEM characterization were conducted. As indicated in Fig. 4 A, the Co3O4 microcrystals in the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst are irregular with the presence of some angular structures in addition to the basic spherical grains. The upper right part of the Fig. 4 A was enlarged to obtain the Fig. 4 B. This magnified image exhibited structural features of the “Yardang landform”, which was the same as that of 3.0F-Co3O4 as described in our previous study [23]. This was due to the “etching” effect of F127 during the preparation process, which makes the Co3O4 crystallite presence this complex surface structure. The above structure indicates that the addition of Bi does not change the morphological structure of Co3O4 crystalline in 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst. To conduct more detailed analysis of the exposure of crystal plane by different catalysts, four distinct regions in the Fig. 4 A were selected for sequential enlarging, resulting in the Fig. 4 C-F. In our previous study, it was observed that the exposed crystal planes of Co3O4(P) catalyst (prepared by traditional precipitation method) mainly were (111) and (311), which were (111), (422) for 0F-Co3O4 catalyst (without assistance of F127) and (400), (511) for 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst [23]. The exposure of special crystal planes (such as (400) and (511)) plays an important role in changing catalyst's activity. For 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst reported in this study, in addition to the crystal planes mentioned above, more (222) and some (442), (533) and (620) crystal planes were observed. However, it is worth noting that the (511) crystal plane, which was present in the original 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst, was not detected in this analysis. It means the addition of Bi can influence the exposure of specific crystal planes to some extent. Although, it is impossible to determine the exact exposure density of each crystal plane, the exposure of various special crystal planes could potentially contribute to the remarkable catalytic efficacy of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst for N2O decomposition. In addition, In the HRTEM image of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst (Fig. 4 E), the presence of (222) (d = 1.95 Å) and (320) (d = 2.12 Å) corresponding to Bi2O3 can be observed, which further proved that Bi dispersed on the surface of Co3O4 in the form of Bi2O3 for 3.0F-Bi0.015Co prepared by improved sol-gel method. 3.2 Surface properties analysis To explore the surface chemistry of the Bi-modified 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst (3.0F-Bi0.015Co) and its relationship with the catalytic performance, XPS characterization of 3.0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalysts were carried out. Fig. 5 A was the full-scan XPS spectra of two catalysts, which clearly revealed the presence of Bi 4f spectra peak at 168∼154 eV in the XPS spectra of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst. Fig. 5 B exhibited the narrow scan of Bi 4f spectra of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co, the binding energy was located at two peaks of ∼ 163.9 and ∼ 158.6 eV, which corresponded to Bi 4f5/2 and Bi 4f7/2 of Bi2O3, respectively [21,32]. It also indicated that additive Bi of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was present in the form of Bi2O3, which was consistent with the analysis results of XRD and HRTEM. The Co 2p XPS spectra of 3.0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalysts were shown in the Fig. 5 C. Both 3.0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi0.015Co showed the presence of the Co 2p peaks at ∼ 796 eV and ∼ 780 eV, which corresponded to the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 orbitals of Co3O4 spinel, respectively [23,31,33]. As seen from the figure, due to the doping of Bi, the Co 2p3/2 peak of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst shifted from 780.6 to 779.6 eV compared with 3.0F-Co3O4, which proved that the interaction between Bi2O3 and Co3O4 weakened the surface Co-O bond [33,34]. A more detailed peak splitting of the Co 2p3/2 spectra was carried out and the atomic ratios of Co3+/Co2+ were calculated for the different catalysts, as shown in Table 1 . The catalyst with the introduction of Bi reached a ratio of 1.57, which also exceed the Co3+/Co2+ ratio in 3.0F-Co3O4 (1.46). It suggested that the redox capacity of Co3O4 in the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was enhanced due to the addition of Bi [35]. Similarly, the O 1 s peaks of each catalyst were split peak fitted. As displayed in Fig. 5 D, the O 1 s of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst can be fitted to three peaks located at 530.0 eV, 531.7 eV, and 529.6 eV, which represented surface oxygen adsorbed on the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα1), oxygen adsorbed on the molecular water on the surface of the catalyst (Oα2), and surface lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively [23]. The proportion of Oα1 species in the total oxygen species was calculated based on the respective peak areas and collated in Table 1. Compared with the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst, the percentage of surface adsorbed oxygen decreased slightly after the introduction of Bi additives (from 0.683 to 0.620), which was attributed to the fact that Bi species mainly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts, and occupying some of the active sites. Moreover, the atomic ratio of Bi/Co on the catalyst surface, as determined by XPS, stands at 0.065. This value was notably higher than the stoichiometric ratio of the Bi(NO3)3·5H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O precursors used in the preparation process (0.015). It can also be proved that the additives added are highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst. During the catalytic N2O decomposition process, the cleavage of the NO bond releases N2 to generate adsorbed oxygen (O*). Upon desorption of the adsorbed oxygen (O*), the active site is regenerated, completing the entire catalytic cycle [23]. Consequently, it is widely acknowledged that the desorption of adsorbed oxygen is intricately linked to the active site on the catalyst surface, and the oxygen vacancies are considered to be the active sites for catalyzing N2O decomposition [36,37]. Hence, O2-TPD experiments were performed to study the desorption behavior of deposited oxygen species on the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. As shown in the Fig. 6 , the peak area can be converted to obtain the corresponding amount of deoxidation, and then the number of active sites can also be calculated [16]. As shown in the figure, the oxygen desorption peak of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co and 3.0F-Co3O4 were almost identical in the temperature range of 100–300 °C. After calculation, the number of active sites on the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was 63.72 μmol g −1, which was slightly reduced compared with that (77.62 μmol g −1) on 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst. Of course, the calculated oxygen vacancy density (3.35 µmol m −2) of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was also lower than that (7.76 µmol m −2) of the 3.0F-Co3O4. This was due to the precipitation of the doped Bi on the surface, covering part of the active sites, as proved by EDS and XPS. 3.3 Catalytic performance for 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar The catalytic performance of 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi x Co (x = 0–0.2) catalysts for N2O decomposition was tested and the results were displayed in the Fig. 7 . From the figure, it can be found that the catalytic activity for N2O decomposition over 0F-Co3O4 was very poor, only 9.5 % N2O conversion can be obtained at 350 °C. Meanwhile, the N2O conversion over the prepared 3.0F-Co3O4 can reach to ∼80 % at 350 °C [23]. This undoubtedly underscores the importance of F127 in the catalyst preparation process. When Bi as additive for the 3.0F-Bi x Co series catalysts, the catalytic activity has been further improved. The N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Bi x Co catalysts first increased and then decreased with the increase of Bi dosage, and reached the highest at Bi/Co = 0.015. For example, the N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was 88.5 % at 300 °C, which was about 1.77 times of that (50 %) over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst. It suggested that the catalytic activity of the catalyst significantly improved as a result of the interactions between the Bi species and Co3O4. 3.4 Reaction kinetics study According to previous reports, it is well-known that the deN2O reaction over the cobalt-based catalysts followed first order kinetics [37]. In this part, the specific reaction rate ( r ) and reaction rate constant ( k ) for the catalytic N2O decomposition reaction over 3.0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Bi0. 0 15Co catalysts were calculated, and the results were listed in the Table 2 . As shown in the table, the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst exhibited a higher specific reaction rate compared with 3.0F-Co3O4. For instance, the r of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was 0.176 μmol s −1 g −1 at 250 °C, which was 2.44 times higher than that (0.072 μmol s −1 g −1) of the 3.0F-Co3O4. Further, the TOF of the reaction over the two catalysts at different temperature were also calculated. The TOF value of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was 2.33 × 10−3 s −1 at 250 °C, while it was only 7.95 × 10−4 s −1 for 3.0F-Co3O4. It indicated that although the number of active sites of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was slightly reduced compared with 3.0F-Co3O4, the average catalytic capacity for single active site was substantially increased due to the introduction of Bi. Meanwhile, the E a of reaction over the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was calculated according to the Arrhenius formula and the value of the activation energy was 47.0 kJ mol−1, which was remarkably lower than that (55.0 kJ mol−1) of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst. In conclusion, it indicated that the doping of large radius metal Bi can weak Co-O bonds on the surface of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts, reduce the E a and increase the responsiveness of a single active site to facilitate deN2O efficiently. 3.5 The influence of impurity gases Based on the above analysis, Bi doping into the catalysts synthesized by sol-gel method resulted in catalysts with excellent catalytic properties. Fig. 8 and Fig. S1 compared the influence of different impurity gases (5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol.% H2O) on the catalytic performance of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. It can be found that the T 90 (temperature when N2O conversation achieves 90 %) of two catalysts was 302 °C and 371 °C under ideal conditions (2000 ppmv N2O/Ar). When 5 vol.% O2 or 2 vol.% H2O was introduced into the reaction system, the T 90 of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst increased to 333 and 335 °C, while the T 90 of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst increased to 399 and 402 °C, respectively. It was evident that O2 and H2O had little effect on the catalytic activity for 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalysts. In contrast, when 100 ppmv of NO was introduced into the reaction system, the T 90 of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst increased to 361 °C, whereas the T 90 of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst increased to 395 °C, resulting in an increment of 59 °C and 24 °C, respectively. For the catalyst with the introduction of Bi, the sensitivity to NO was stronger than that of the catalysts without the introduction of additives probably because some of the crystalline surfaces exposed by this catalyst have poor resistance to NO [23]. Based on the above, this is corroborated by the fact that when 100 ppmv NO and 5 vol.% O2 were co-vented into the reaction system, the T 90 of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst rose to 382 °C, and that of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst rose to 404 °C, with incremental increases of 80 °C and 33 °C, respectively. This further confirmed the aforementioned observations. Finally, all three impurity gases (O2, NO and H2O) were co-introduced into the reaction gas stream, and the T 90 of the catalyst was 399 °C. However, it was 433 °C for the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst at the same reaction condition. Although the T 90 of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst increased by nearly 100 °C after all three impurity gases are introduced, it still can maintain above 90 % N2O conversion at 400 °C. Fig. 9 exhibited the performance of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst in N2O conversion changed with time on stream when some of impurity gases (O2, NO and H2O) were injected in or cut off from the feed stream at 350 °C and 400 °C. When the NO, O2 and H2O were injected into the feed gas in turn at 350 °C, the N2O conversion rate decreased to ∼ 95 %, ∼ 30 % and ∼ 25 %, respectively. Herein, it should be noticed that the activity did not continue to decline significantly after injection of H2O, which was because of that the active sites were almost occupied by NO x and subsequent H2O could not continue to compete for the remaining active sites. During the continuous reaction over the next 9 h, the N2O conversion rate on the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst remained consistently around 25 %, which indicated the catalytic stability of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst over the extended reaction period. Then, the impurity gas was turned off successively and the catalytic activity of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was restored to 100 %. When the temperature was raised to 400 °C and all the impurity gas was introduced, the catalyst could still maintain the N2O conversion rate at ∼ 90 % for 16 h without attenuation. The N2O conversion rate quickly increased to 100 % after cutting off all the impurity gas from the reaction system. All the above phenomena indicate that the competitive adsorption of impurity gases and N2O at the active site is the reason for the decrease of N2O conversion. Different impurity gases (O2, H2O, NO x ) all have an effect on the kinetic level of catalytic deN2O. Furthermore, although the additive Bi did not improve the catalyst's ability to resist NO x , it is undeniable that the addition of Bi improved the catalytic activity under the presence the impurity gases at relatively mild reaction conditions (400 °C), which was better than most catalysts reported in the literatures, as shown in the Table S1 [14,16,18,23,30,38-41]. 4 Conclusions In general, the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co composite oxide catalyst has been synthesized successfully in one step by sol-gel method with the assistance of F127 and used for catalyzing N2O decomposition. It was found that under the given catalyst preparation conditions, since the ion radius of Bi3+ is much larger than that of Co2+, Bi did not enter the Co3O4 lattice, but highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst in the form of Bi2O3. Due to this reason, the specific surface area of the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst was increased by nearly 1 time compared with that of 3.0F-Co3O4. Surface characteristic research showed that the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst has weaker Co-O bonds and more abundant surface Co3+ species than 3.0F-Co3O4. Although the active site number of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was slightly lower than that of 3.0F-Co3O4, the TOF value of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was 2.9 times of that of 3.0F-Co3O4 at 250 °C. Meanwhile, the Ea of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was as low as 47.0 kJ mol−1. For the above reasons, 3.0F-Bi0.015Co exhibited higher catalytic activity compared with 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst. 100 % N2O conversion can be obtained at 350 °C with the feed gas of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar, GHSV=20,000 h −1. Besides, the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst displayed outstanding catalytic stability and resistance performance to H2O and O2. It can maintain 90 % N2O conversion at 400 °C for 16 h under the presence of O2, NO and H2O. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, Bi promoted Co3O4 catalysts used for catalyzing N2O decomposition were successfully prepared by improved sol-gel method with the assistance of F127. It was found that the doping of additive Bi not only did not change the unique “Yardang Landform” microstructure of the 3.0F-Co3O4, but also prompted Co3O4 to expose more active crystal planes, such as (422), (533) and (620). Moreover, the doping of the additive Bi also enhanced the catalyst's specific surface area, and further weakened the surface Co-O bond. The optimum 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst achieved >88 % N2O conversion (2000 ppmv N2O/Ar, GHSV=20,000 h −1) at 300 °C, and its corresponding TOF value increased from 1.50 × 10−3 s −1 for 3.0F-Co3O4 to 3.63 × 10−3 s −1. Meanwhile, the Ea of 3.0F-Bi0.015Co was as low as 47.0 kJ mol−1. Most importantly, the catalyst has good resistance to O2 and H2O. Under the harsh condition (both 5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol.% H2O were coexisted in the reaction system), the N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Bi0.015Co catalyst can be stable above 90 % at 400 °C.
